summary:
We examine measure preserving mappings $f$ acting from a probability space
$(\Omega, F,\mu) $ into a probability space $% (\Omega ^{*},F^{*},\mu ^{*}) ,$
where $\mu ^{*}=\mu (f^{-1})$. Conditions on $f$, under which $f$ preserves the
relations ''to be singular'' and ''to be absolutely continuous'' between
measures defined on $(\Omega, F) $ and corresponding image measures, are
investigated.
  We apply the results to investigate the distribution of the random variable
$% \xi =\sum\limits^{\infty}_{k=1} \xi_k\lambda ^k,$ where $% \lambda \in
(0;1),$ and $\xi_k$ are independent not necessarily identically distributed
random variables taking the values $i$ with probabilities $% p_{ik}$ ,$i=0,1.$
  We also studied in details the metric-topological and fractal properties of
the distribution of a random variable $\psi = \sum\limits^{\infty}_{k=1} \xi
_ka_k,$ where $a_k>0$ are terms of the convergent series.

Let S⊥ be the set of those λ ∈ [ 12 ; 1) for which the random variable ξ
has singular distribution, and let S≪ be the set of those λ ∈ ( 21 ; 1) for which
the measure P ξ is absolutely continuous (with respect to Lebesgue measure
L). In 1939 P. Erdös [5] proved that λ ∈ S⊥ whenever λ is the reciprocal of
a Pisot number in (1; 2). Up to now we do not know any other examples
of λ belonging to S⊥ . In 1940 P. Erdös proved the existence a number a
independent of λ such that almost all λ from (a; 1) belong to S≪ . In 1962
A. Garsia [6] found the largest explicitly described subset of S≪ known up
to now. Garsia formulated the following conjecture: almost all λ ∈ [ 12 ; 1)
belong to S≪ . This conjecture was proved by B.Solomyak[19] in 1995, a
simpler proof was found by Y. Peres and B.Solomyak in [14]. In [15] a more
general nonsymmetric model was considered by Y. Peres and B.Solomyak:
if the ξk in (1) take values −1 and +1 with probabilities 1 − p and p (p ∈
[ 31 ; 32 ])correspondingly, then almost all λ from [pp (1 −p)(1−p) ; 1) belong to S≪ .
